question: A.001  (1.0 point)  Which of the following statements best characterizes Natural Circulation?

answers.answer: a. It needs a pump to get started.
answers.feedback: Incorrect.  Reference:General Physics, HT&FF, pp. 355 - 358

answers.answer: b. The elevation of the heat source must be above that of the heat sink.
answers.feedback: Incorrect.  Reference:General Physics, HT&FF, pp. 355 - 358

answers.answer: c. The driving force is a difference in density.
answers.feedback: Correct.  Reference:General Physics, HT&FF, pp. 355 - 358

answers.answer: d. Heat transfer is more efficient if steam is mixed with water.
answers.feedback: Incorrect.  Reference:General Physics, HT&FF, pp. 355 - 358

question: A.002  (1.0 point) Which one of the following is the reason for operating with thermal neutrons instead of fast neutrons?

answers.answer: a. Neutron absorption in non-fuel material increases exponentially as neutron energy increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Nuclear Energy Training, Module 3, 1.5-2 and 2.6-1.

answers.answer: b. Doppler and moderator temperature coefficients become positive as neutron energy increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Nuclear Energy Training, Module 3, 1.5-2 and 2.6-1.

answers.answer: c. The fission cross section of the fuel is much higher for thermal energy neutrons than fast neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:Nuclear Energy Training, Module 3, 1.5-2 and 2.6-1.

answers.answer: d. Increased neutron efficiency since thermal neutrons are less likely to leak out of the core than fast neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Nuclear Energy Training, Module 3, 1.5-2 and 2.6-1.

question: A.003  (1.0 point) Which one of the following is the definition for INTEGRAL ROD WORTH? Integral Rod Worth is defined as the reactivity:

answers.answer: a. due to control rod position.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:Nuclear Energy Training Module 3 Section 7 page 7.5-1

answers.answer: b. change per unit of rod motion.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Nuclear Energy Training Module 3 Section 7 page 7.5-1

answers.answer: c. due to the difference in a control rods position.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Nuclear Energy Training Module 3 Section 7 page 7.5-1

answers.answer: d. still available for shutdown after control rod withdrawal.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Nuclear Energy Training Module 3 Section 7 page 7.5-1

question: A.004  (1.0 point)  {4.0} Given the associated graph,  Which of the following answers best describe the neutron behavior within Region II?

answers.answer: a. The neutron cross section is inversely proportional to the neutron velocity (1/V)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2

answers.answer: b. The neutron cross section decreases steadily with increasing neutron energy (1/E).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2

answers.answer: c. Neutrons of specific energy levels (e.g., 50 ev, 100 kev) have a greater potential for leakage from the reactor core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2

answers.answer: d. Neutrons of specific energy levels (e.g., 50 ev, 100 kev) are more likely to be readily absorbed than neutrons at other energy levels.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2

question: A.005  (1.0 point)   Regulating rod worth for a reactor is 0.001 ΔK/K/inch.  Moderator temperature increases by 9ºF, and the regulating rod moves 4½ inches inward to compensate.  The moderator temperature coefficient αTmod is …

answers.feedback:
Correct. Reference: OSU Training Manual Vol. 3, p. 19
Also,     (4.5 × 0.001) ÷ 9 = 0.0045 ÷ 9 = 0.0005 = 5 × 10-4

Incorrect. Reference:OSU Training Manual Vol. 3, p. 19
Also,     (4.5 × 0.001) ÷ 9 = 0.0045 ÷ 9 = 0.0005 = 5 × 10-4

Incorrect. Reference:OSU Training Manual Vol. 3, p. 19
Also,     (4.5 × 0.001) ÷ 9 = 0.0045 ÷ 9 = 0.0005 = 5 × 10-4

Incorrect. Reference:OSU Training Manual Vol. 3, p. 19
Also,     (4.5 × 0.001) ÷ 9 = 0.0045 ÷ 9 = 0.0005 = 5 × 10-4

question: A.006  (1.0 point) Which ONE of the following describes the MAJOR contributor to the production and depletion of Xenon respectively in a STEADY-STATE OPERATING reactor?

answers.answer: a. Radioactive decay of Iodine and Tellurium  Radioactive Decay
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Oregon State University Training Manual Volume 3, Reactor Operation and     Xenon Poisoning, p. 22, 1st ¶.

answers.answer: b. Radioactive decay of Iodine and Tellurium   Neutron Absorption
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:Oregon State University Training Manual Volume 3, Reactor Operation and     Xenon Poisoning, p. 22, 1st ¶.

answers.answer: c. Directly from fission     Radioactive Decay
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Oregon State University Training Manual Volume 3, Reactor Operation and     Xenon Poisoning, p. 22, 1st ¶.

answers.answer: d. Directly from fission     Neutron Absorption
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Oregon State University Training Manual Volume 3, Reactor Operation and     Xenon Poisoning, p. 22, 1st ¶.

question: A.007  (1.0 point) Which one of the following is the description of a thermal neutron?

answers.answer: a. A neutron possessing thermal rather than kinetic energy.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Generic

answers.answer: b. The primary source of thermal energy increase in the reactor coolant during reactor operation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Generic

answers.answer: c. A neutron that experiences no net change in energy after several collisions with atoms of the diffusing media.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:Generic

answers.answer: d. A neutron that has been produced in a significant time (on the order of seconds) after its initiating fission took place.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Generic

question: A.008  (1.0 point) Which one of the following reactions describes how 7Nitrogen16 is produced? 7 Oxygen 16:

answers.answer: a. absorbes a neutron then decays by proton emition.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Chart of the Nuclides

answers.answer: b. decays by neutron emition then absorbes a proton
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Chart of the Nuclides

answers.answer: c. absorbes a proton then decays by neutron emition
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Chart of the Nuclides

answers.answer: d. decays by a proton emition then absorbes a neutron
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Chart of the Nuclides

question:
A.009  (1.0 point)   Given the following Primary System Parameters.
Reactor Pool Volume   14,250 gals
Reactor Pool Temperature  104 F
Reactor Power Level   1 MW
 Which one of the following is the amount of time that is available before the reactor is scrammed, at 118 F pool temperature, when primary coolant flow is lost?

answers.answer: a. 15 minutes
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:

answers.answer: b. 22 minutes
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:

answers.answer: c. 29 minutes
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:

answers.answer: d. 36 minutes
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:

question: A.010  (1.0 point)   The number of neutrons passing through a square centimeter per second is the definition of  Which ONE of the following?

answers.answer: a. Neutron Population (np)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

answers.answer: b. Neutron Impact Potential (nip)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

answers.answer: c. Neutron Flux (nv)
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

answers.answer: d. Neutron Density (nd)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

question: A.011  (1.0 point)   The Fast Fission Factor (ε) is defined as “The ratio of the number of neutrons produced by …

answers.answer: a. fast fission  to the number produced by thermal fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:NEEP 234, p. 89.

answers.answer: b. thermal fission  to the number produced by fast fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:NEEP 234, p. 89.

answers.answer: c. fast and thermal fission to the number produced by thermal fission.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:NEEP 234, p. 89.

answers.answer: d. fast fission to the number produced by fast and thermal fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:NEEP 234, p. 89.

question: A.012  (1.0 point) Which statement illustrates a characteristic of Subcritical Multiplication?

answers.answer: a. The number of source neutrons decreases for each generation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Nuclear Training Manual

answers.answer: b. The number of fission neutrons remain constant for each generation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Nuclear Training Manual

answers.answer: c. The number of neutrons gained per generation gets larger for each succeeding generation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Nuclear Training Manual

answers.answer: d. As Keff approaches unity (1), for the same increase in Keff, a greater increase in neutron   population occurs.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:Nuclear Training Manual

question: A.013  (1.0 point)   The purpose of the installed neutron source is to:

answers.answer: a. Compensate for neutrons absorbed in non-fuel materials in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: b. Provide a means to allow reactivity changes to occur in a subcritical reactor.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: c. Generate a sufficient neutron population to start the fission chain reaction for each startup.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: d. Generate a detectable neutron source level for monitoring reactivity changes in a    shutdown reactor.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

question: A.014  (1.0 point)   During a fuel loading of the core, as the reactor approaches criticality, the value of 1/M:

answers.answer: a. Increases toward one
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, pg. 5-18

answers.answer: b. Decreases toward one
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, pg. 5-18

answers.answer: c. Increases toward infinity
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, pg. 5-18

answers.answer: d. Decreases toward zero
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, pg. 5-18

question: A.015  (1.0 point) Which ONE of the following is the definition of the term “Cross-Section?”

answers.answer: a. The probability that a neutron will be captured by a nucleus.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982

answers.answer: b. The most likely energy at  Which a charge particle will be captured.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982

answers.answer: c. The length a charged particle travels past the nucleus before being captured.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982

answers.answer: d. The area of the nucleus including the electron cloud.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982

question: A.016  (1.0 point)  {16.0}  Which ONE of the following coefficients will be the first one to start turning reactor power after a power excursion?

answers.answer: a. Moderator Coefficient
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2

answers.answer: b. Void Coefficient
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2

answers.answer: c. Doppler Coefficient
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2

answers.answer: d. Poisons buildup
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2

question: A.017  (1.0 point)   Why does the fuel temperature (Doppler) coefficient becomes less negative at higher fuel temperatures?

answers.answer: a. As reactor power increases, the rate of increase in the fuel temperature diminishes.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:FNRE pg. 146, 149

answers.answer: b. Neutrons penetrate deeper into the fuel, resulting in an increase in the fast fission factor.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:FNRE pg. 146, 149

answers.answer: c. The amount of self-shielding increases, resulting in less neutron absorption by the inner fuel.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:FNRE pg. 146, 149

answers.answer: d. The broadening of the resonance peaks diminishes per degree change in fuel temperature.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:FNRE pg. 146, 149

question:
A.018  (1.0 point)   When performing rod calibrations, many facilities pull the rod out a given increment, then measure the time for reactor power to double (doubling time), then calculate the reactor period.
If the doubling time is 42 seconds, what is the reactor period?

answers.answer: a. 29 sec
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:ln (2) = -time/τ     τ = time/(ln(2)) = 60.59 approx. 61 seconds

answers.answer: b. 42 sec
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:ln (2) = -time/τ     τ = time/(ln(2)) = 60.59 approx. 61 seconds

answers.answer: c. 61 sec
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:ln (2) = -time/τ     τ = time/(ln(2)) = 60.59 approx. 61 seconds

answers.answer: d. 84 sec
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:ln (2) = -time/τ     τ = time/(ln(2)) = 60.59 approx. 61 seconds

question: A.019  (1.0 point)   INELASTIC SCATTERING is the process by  Which a neutron collides with a nucleus and …

answers.answer: a. recoils with the same kinetic energy it had prior to the collision.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, pg. 2-28

answers.answer: b. is absorbed, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray, and the neutron with a lower kinetic energy.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, pg. 2-28

answers.answer: c. is absorbed, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, pg. 2-28

answers.answer: d. recoils with a higher kinetic energy than it had prior to the collision with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, pg. 2-28

question: A.020  (1.0 point)   The reactor supervisor tells you that the Keff for the reactor is 0.955.  How much reactivity must you add to the reactor to reach criticality?
